entry.content:
Big Projects

  • Wikipedia Current Events Analysis
  • Virtual Reality Surface Viewer

Small Projects

  • Anki Command Line Tool
  • Sudoku Solver
  • Database Browser
  • Virtual Reality Cube Menu

Wikipedia Current Events Analysis

[This project is still in progress]

What

  • Web scraper to get around 300 pages or 100,000 news headlines from Wikipedia. Can be run as a command line tool
  • Script to clean each headline and its metadata
  • Jupyter notebook to visualize trends and analyze entire dataset
  • Jupyter notebook to perform various machine learning tasks such as predicting what year a headline is from

Why

  • I often check the Wikipedia current events portal and was curious what types of events are the most popular and how that has changed in the 26 years wikipedia has been sharing these headlines

How

  • BeautifulSoup (for scraping Wikipedia pages)
  • Regular expressions (for extracting data and parsing HTML documents)
  • Pandas and Matplotlib (for exploratory data analysis)
  • NLTK (for text cleaning and natural language processing)
  • Sklearn (for predictive modelling)

Where

  • Github
  • Blog post

When

  • November 2020

For more information, please see the blog post


Virtual Reality Surface Viewer

What

  • Virtual reality scene to view 3d mathematical surfaces from NIST's Digital Library which is also accessible as a webpage
    • Rotation, scaling, shading, axes, selection, can be changed using Oculus Rift
  • Command line tool to convert 3d object files into other common formats

Why

  • Experimental environment for seeing how to interact with 3d objects in virtual reality for research and intuition purposes

How

  • A-Frame (JavaScript Virtual Reality Framework)
  • NodeJS (for CLI)
  • HTML and CSS (for NIST website)

Where

  • NIST website
  • Virtual Reality Scene
  • Presentation slides
  • Blog post

When

  • Summer 2019, National Insitute of Standards and Technology (NIST)

For more information, please see the blog post


Anki Command Line Tool

What

  • Command line tool to convert to interact with Anki flashcards and decks
    • Get information on decks
    • Add a card from the command line
    • Add many cards into a deck from a csv file (instead of manually inputting)

Why

  • I am a frequent user of anki and wanted to interact with their API and make the annoying process of making flashcards easier

How

  • Python
  • Argparse
  • ankiconnect api

Where

  • Github
  • Blog post

When

  • January 2020

For more information, please see the blog post


Sudoku Solver

What

  • Simple script which attempts to solve a Sudoku grid
    • Checks if rest of 3x3 box is filled
    • Checks if other 8 of the same number is filled in
    • Checks if 2 of the same number force the third's place

Why

  • I wanted to practice object oriented programming and see how I could put common Sudoku strategies into code

How

  • Python
  • Object-oriented programming
  • Unittest
  • Numpy

Where

  • Github
  • Blog post

When

  • January 2020

For more information, please see the blog post


Database Browser

What

  • User interface allowing you to select a database, view the rows, and filter rows by user-inputted values.

Why

  • I wanted to practice object oriented programming and see how I could put common Sudoku strategies into code

How

  • Python
  • Tkinter
  • sqlite

Where

  • Github
  • Blog post

When

  • January 2020

For more information, please see the blog post


Virtual Reality Cube Menu

What

  • Cube attached to the hand in a virtual reality environment for easy manipulation of buttons and other settings
    • Buttons
    • Rotation to see all sides (or menus) on the cube
    • Laser for selecting options
    • Customization of shape, size, and colors

Why

  • I had extra time during my internship at NIST to experiment with new virtual reality user interfaces

How

  • JavaScript
  • Aframe
  • HTML
  • Oculus rift

Where

  • Github
  • Blog post

When

  • Summer 2019, National Insitute of Standards and Technology (NIST)

For more information, please see the blog post

entry.title: Wikipedia Current News Analysis
entry.content:
Please see the general info for this project on the Projects page

I split this project into 3 parts:

  1. Collecting the data
  2. Exploring and understanding the data
  3. Machine learning tasks (in progress)
